required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Progressive Elastic Band Resistance Training
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Progressive Elastic Band Resistance Training on Body Composition and Motor Performance in Adults With Prader-Willi Syndrome: a Pilot Study

lead_sponsor.agency: Taipei Tzu Chi Hospital, Buddhist Tzu Chi Medical Foundation

clinical_study.source: Taipei Tzu Chi Hospital, Buddhist Tzu Chi Medical Foundation

brief_summary.textblock: Abnormal body composition with increased body fat mass and decreased lean body mass has been found in adults with Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS), contributing to reduced physical capacity and impairment. The aim of this study was to investigate whether progressive elastic band resistance training can improve physical motor performance and regional body composition in adults with PWS.

detailed_description.textblock: Six participants were enrolled in this pilot study. Following 24 weeks of progressive elastic band resistance exercise training, significant reduction was observed in their body weight, BMI, and regional extremities fat mass and percentage. Regarding the functional performances, there were also significant improvements in their hand grip strength, 3 meter timed up and go, 30 seconds sit to stand, and 2-min step up tests, as early as the 8th week of training. Balance function achieved significant improvements after 16 weeks of training.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in the handgrip strength functional physical assessment
primary_outcome.time_frame: Changes from Baseline functional motor performance tests at 8 weeks, 16 weeks and 24 weeks

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in the 30 second chair stand functional physical assessment
primary_outcome.time_frame: Changes from Baseline functional motor performance tests at 8 weeks, 16 weeks and 24 weeks

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in the timed up and go functional physical assessment
primary_outcome.time_frame: Changes from Baseline functional motor performance tests at 8 weeks, 16 weeks and 24 weeks

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in the two minute step up functional physical assessment
primary_outcome.time_frame: Changes from Baseline functional motor performance tests at 8 weeks, 16 weeks and 24 weeks

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in the balance functional physical assessment
primary_outcome.time_frame: Changes from Baseline functional motor performance tests at 8 weeks, 16 weeks and 24 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Berg Balance Scale (0-56 points; 0-20= high fall risk; 21-40= medium fall risk; 41-56= low fall risk)

primary_outcome.measure: Change in the BMI body composition
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline body composition components at 6 months
primary_outcome.description: Body weight (km) and height (m) will be combined to report as BMI (kg/m2)

primary_outcome.measure: Change in the percentage of body fat of body composition
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline body composition components at 6 months

primary_outcome.measure: Change in the body fat mass of body composition
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline body composition components at 6 months

primary_outcome.measure: Change in the lean body mass of body composition
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline body composition components at 6 months

arm_group.description: Genetically confirmed diagnosis of PWS participants were recruited. The PWS participants needed to have sufficient command of the Mandarin language to understand the study information and motivated to conduct the training program.

intervention.description: PWS participants received 9 sets exercises for the major muscle groups, over 24 weeks, three times a week, for a total of 72 sessions.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- PWS individuals who can cooperate with motor performances
Exclusion Criteria:
- arthritis, fracture, or severe musculoskeletal deformities that would interfere with exercise training or motor performance
- severe cognitive impairment or parents who cannot read nor write.

overall_official.affiliation: Taipei Tzu Chi Hospital, Buddhist Tzu Chi Foundation

results_reference.citation: Schlumpf M, Eiholzer U, Gygax M, Schmid S, van der Sluis I, l'Allemand D. A daily comprehensive muscle training programme increases lean mass and spontaneous activity in children with Prader-Willi syndrome after 6 months. J Pediatr Endocrinol Metab. 2006 Jan;19(1):65-74.
Eiholzer U, Nordmann Y, l'Allemand D, Schlumpf M, Schmid S, Kromeyer-Hauschild K. Improving body composition and physical activity in Prader-Willi Syndrome. J Pediatr. 2003 Jan;142(1):73-8.
